bibl.title: Letter from S.B. Grubbs to Henry Rose Carter, December 12, 1924

div1.p: Grubbs writes that he has no knowledge of any plague epidemic aboard a ship.

div1.head: Letter from S.B. Grubbs to Henry Rose Carter, December 12, 1924
div1.opener:
Book
Plague
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
U. S. QUARANTINE STATION
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
ROSEBANK
STATEN ISLAND, N.Y.
December 12, 1924.
SBG:DCH
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2122 California St., N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Replying to your letter of November 29th, 1924,
I have no personal knowledge of bubonic plague on the
high seas that could be called an epidemic, nor do I know
of any pneumonic plague aboard ship.

All the officers on this station have been
questioned and none of them know of any such occurrence.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, S. B. Grubbs,
Surgeon, U.S.P.H.S.,
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE.
